Samsung.OF: The refrigerator is in 'Demo' mode, where cooling is turned off to save power. To exit this mode, disconnect the refrigerator from power and reconnect it, or press the 'Energy Saver' and 'Freezer' buttons together for 3 seconds.
Samsung.PC: Disconnection between the door and the main cooling unit. Check that the door is properly closed and that there are no disconnected cables around it. If there are cables that can be connected, disconnect the refrigerator from power, connect the cables, and then reconnect the power.
Samsung.ER: Disconnection between the door and the main cooling unit. Check that the door is properly closed and that there are no disconnected cables around it. If there are cables that can be connected, disconnect the refrigerator from power, connect the cables, and then reconnect the power.
Samsung.1E: Freezer sensor malfunction. Check that there is no ice buildup in the freezer. If there is, defrost the freezer and reset the display by pressing 'Energy Saver' and 'Lighting' together.
Samsung.2E: Freezer sensor malfunction. Check that there is no ice buildup in the freezer. If there is, defrost the freezer and reset the display by pressing 'Energy Saver' and 'Lighting' together.

Sharp.E09: The freezer compartment is not cold enough. This likely happens after a prolonged power outage. Set the freezer temperature to a lower value or activate the 'Quick Freeze' function. Keep the doors closed to speed up cooling. If the warning persists, contact Sharp's service center.
Sharp.E10: The refrigerator compartment is not cold enough. This likely happens after a prolonged power outage or after placing hot food in the refrigerator. Set the refrigerator temperature to a lower value or activate the 'Quick Cooling' function. Keep the doors closed to speed up cooling. If the warning persists, contact Sharp's service center.
Sharp.E11: The refrigerator compartment is too cold. Check if the 'Quick Cooling' function is activated, lower the refrigerator compartment temperature, and ensure the air vents are not blocked. If the warning persists, contact Sharp's service center.

Electrolux.OP: Freezer temperature sensor open circuit. Check the wiring connections between the freezer temperature sensor and the electronic control board. If the connections are fine, measure the sensor resistance and replace it if necessary.

LG.OFF: The refrigerator is in 'Demo' mode, where cooling and freezing are turned off to save power. To exit this mode, open the refrigerator door and press the 'Refrigerator' and 'Ice Plus' buttons for 5 seconds. After pressing, the display panel should show the refrigerator temperature.

Samsung.E101: The outdoor unit is not responding to the indoor unit for more than one minute. Check the proper connection of the power and control cables between the units, and ensure there are no shorts in the wires.
Samsung.E121: Room temperature sensor error. Check the sensor connection to the control board. If the connection is correct, measure the sensor resistance; at 25C, the resistance should be 103% kilo-ohms. If the value is different, replace the sensor.
Samsung.E1: Error in the room air temperature sensor. The sensor may be improperly connected or faulty. Check the connection and replace the sensor if needed.
Samsung.E2: Error in the battery temperature sensor in the indoor unit. The sensor may be improperly connected or faulty. Check the connection and replace the sensor if needed.
Samsung.E3: Error in the battery temperature sensor in the outdoor unit. The sensor may be improperly connected or faulty. Check the connection and replace the sensor if needed.
Samsung.E4: Error in the fan motor of the indoor unit or the electronic control board. The fan motor capacitor may be burnt and needs replacement. If the motor or board is faulty, replacement may be necessary.
Samsung.E5: Communication error between the indoor and outdoor units. The connecting cable between the units may be torn or disconnected, or there may be a fault in the control board. Check the connection and replace the faulty component if needed.
Samsung.E8: Error in the evaporator battery sensor. The sensor may be reading the temperature incorrectly or may be faulty. Check and replace the sensor if needed.
Samsung.F1: Error in the indoor unit temperature sensor. The sensor may be shorted or disconnected. Check the connection and replace the sensor if needed.
Samsung.F2: Error in the outdoor unit control board. The board may need replacement.
Samsung.F3: Compressor error. There may be a fault in the compressor control board or the compressor itself. Check the components and replace them if needed.
Samsung.F4: Error in the compressor temperature sensor. The sensor may be reading the temperature incorrectly or may be faulty. Check and replace the sensor if needed.
Samsung.P1: The system has entered high-pressure protection mode. The filters or battery may be dirty, or there may be a blockage in the ventilation openings of the outdoor unit. Clean the filters and ensure there are no blockages.
Samsung.P2: The system has entered low-pressure protection mode. The filters may be clogged or there may be a refrigerant shortage. Clean the filters and check the refrigerant pressure.
Samsung.P3: Temperature sensor error. The air conditioner is not detecting the room temperature. Check and replace the sensor if needed.
Samsung.P6: The outdoor unit has entered self-protection mode. There may be a fault in the control board of the outdoor unit or the compressor. Check the components and replace them if needed.

Mitsubishi.E6: Error in the fan motor of the indoor unit. The motor may be faulty or there may be an issue with the electrical connections.
Mitsubishi.E7: Error in the fan motor of the outdoor unit. The motor may be faulty or there may be an issue with the electrical connections.
Mitsubishi.E8: Error in the battery temperature sensor in the outdoor unit. The sensor may be faulty or disconnected.
Mitsubishi.E9: Error in the compressor discharge temperature sensor. The sensor may be faulty or disconnected.
Mitsubishi.F0: Cooling system error. There may be a refrigerant leak or blockage in the system.
Mitsubishi.F1: Error in the returning air temperature sensor in the indoor unit. The sensor may be faulty or disconnected.
Mitsubishi.F2: Error in the outgoing air temperature sensor in the indoor unit. The sensor may be faulty or disconnected.
Mitsubishi.F3: Error in the returning air temperature sensor in the outdoor unit. The sensor may be faulty or disconnected.
Mitsubishi.F4: Error in the outgoing air temperature sensor in the outdoor unit. The sensor may be faulty or disconnected.
Mitsubishi.F5: Error in the compressor discharge temperature sensor. The sensor may be faulty or disconnected.
Mitsubishi.H1: The system is in defrost mode. This is a normal operation where the air conditioner defrosts ice accumulated on the outdoor unit.
Mitsubishi.H3: Compressor overload protection. The compressor may be running at excessive load or there may be an issue with the electrical system.
Mitsubishi.H4: Excessive current protection. There may be a short circuit or the motors are running at excessive load.
Mitsubishi.H5: Error in the IPM (Intelligent Power Module) in the outdoor unit. The module may be faulty and needs replacement.
Mitsubishi.H6: Error in the fan motor of the indoor unit. The motor may be faulty or there may be an issue with the electrical connections.

Amcor.C5: Missing jumper or need for replacing electronic control.
Amcor.H6: Error in the fan motor or board in the indoor unit. Call a technician.
Amcor.F1: Error in the returning air sensor. The sensor may be faulty or disconnected.
Amcor.F0: Error in the condenser. Possible causes: improper connection of the condenser to the system, fault in the condenser board, or refrigerant leak.
Amcor.E8: Communication error between the control board and the compressor. There may be an issue with the electrical connections or the control board.

Tadiran.E1: High system pressure. It may be caused by excess refrigerant, improper connection of the OVC contact on the main board to the high-pressure switch, or loose wiring in the high-pressure switch.
Tadiran.E2: Freeze protection. Possible causes: poor airflow in the indoor unit, improper fan motor speed, or dirt in the evaporator.
Tadiran.E3: Low-pressure compressor protection. It may be caused by a refrigerant shortage or leak, loose wiring in the low-pressure switch, or a faulty low-pressure switch.
Tadiran.E4: High temperature protection at the compressor outlet. Possible causes: system failure (such as blockage), improper fan speed in the outdoor unit, or improper airflow.
Tadiran.E5: Excessive current protection. It may be caused by unstable voltage supply, too low voltage, or overload.
Tadiran.E6: Communication error between the indoor and outdoor units. Possible causes: improper communication line configuration, poor wiring connections, or faulty control.
Tadiran.E8: Error in the battery sensor. The sensor may not be properly connected or may be faulty.
Tadiran.F1: The indoor environment temperature sensor is disconnected or shorted. It may be due to poor wiring contact, faulty sensor, or faulty main board.
Tadiran.F2: The internal evaporator temperature sensor is disconnected or shorted. Possible causes: poor wiring contact, faulty sensor, or faulty main board.
Tadiran.F3: The external environment temperature sensor is disconnected or shorted. The wiring contact may be poor, the sensor may be faulty, or the main board may be faulty.
Tadiran.F4: The external condenser temperature sensor is disconnected or shorted. Possible causes: poor wiring contact, faulty sensor, or faulty main board.
Tadiran.F5: The external unit discharge temperature sensor is disconnected or shorted. It may be due to poor wiring contact, faulty sensor, or faulty main board.
Tadiran.H1: The air conditioner is in defrost mode. This is not a fault; it is a normal mode where the air conditioner defrosts ice accumulated on the outdoor unit.
Tadiran.H3: Automatic compressor overload protection. It may have been caused by overload on the compressor.
Tadiran.H4: Excessive current protection due to abnormal temperature, air short, clogged battery, or fan motor failure.
Tadiran.H5: Error in the IPM module in the condenser board. As a result, all components stop working.
Tadiran.H6: Improper feedback or lack of feedback from the indoor unit motor. It may be due to a faulty GPF connection, a fault in the indoor unit controller, or a fault in the indoor unit motor.

LG.CH01: Error in the indoor air temperature sensor. The sensor may be disconnected or shorted. Check the sensor and replace it if needed.
LG.CH02: Error in the indoor evaporator temperature sensor. The sensor may be disconnected or shorted. Check the sensor and replace it if needed.
LG.CH03: Communication error between the indoor and outdoor units. The connection between the units may be faulty, or there may be an issue with the communication cable. Check the connections and cables.
LG.CH04: Compressor overload protection. The compressor may be overloaded. Check the thermal relay of the outdoor unit, the current load, and the refrigerant pressure in the system.
LG.CH05: Communication error between the indoor and outdoor units. The connecting cable may be damaged, or there may be an issue with the control board. Check the cable and boards and replace them if needed.
LG.CH06: Short-term current spike in the outdoor unit. Check all the actuators of the outdoor unit and the main power relays.
LG.CH07: Extended current overload in the outdoor unit. Check the refrigerant pressure in the system and inspect all components in the outdoor unit.
LG.CH08: Error in the indoor fan motor. Check the motor, control circuit, and its terminal contacts.
LG.CH09: Error in the 4-way valve. Check the valve and its connections.
LG.CH10: Error in the compressor temperature sensor. The sensor may be disconnected or shorted. Check the sensor and replace it if needed.
LG.CH21: Error in the outdoor air temperature sensor. The sensor may be disconnected or shorted. Check the sensor and replace it if needed.
LG.CH22: Error in the outdoor evaporator temperature sensor. The sensor may be disconnected or shorted. Check the sensor and replace it if needed.
LG.CH23: Error in the outdoor condenser temperature sensor. The sensor may be disconnected or shorted. Check the sensor and replace it if needed.
LG.CH32: Error in the outdoor suction pipe temperature sensor. The sensor may be disconnected or shorted. Check the sensor and replace it if needed.
LG.CH33: Error in the outdoor discharge pipe temperature sensor. The sensor may be disconnected or shorted. Check the sensor and replace it if needed.
LG.CH44: Error in the outdoor ambient temperature sensor. The sensor may be disconnected or shorted. Check the sensor and replace it if needed.
LG.CH45: Error in the outdoor discharge pipe temperature sensor. The sensor may be disconnected or shorted. Check the sensor and replace it if needed.
LG.CH46: Error in the outdoor suction pipe temperature sensor. The sensor may be disconnected or shorted. Check the sensor and replace it if needed.
LG.CH60: Error in the defrosting system. There may be an issue with the defrosting sensor or control circuit. Check the system and replace faulty components if needed.
LG.CH61: Error in the outdoor defrosting system. There may be an issue with the defrosting sensor or control circuit. Check the system and replace faulty components if needed.
LG.CH67: Error in the indoor fan motor. The motor may not be operating properly, or there may be an issue with the control circuit. Check the motor and control circuit and replace them if needed.
LG.CH70: Error in the indoor defrosting system. There may be an issue with the defrosting sensor or control circuit. Check the system and replace faulty components if needed.
LG.CH71: Error in the outdoor defrosting system. There may be an issue with the defrosting sensor or control circuit. Check the system and replace faulty components if needed.
LG.CH72: Error in the indoor defrosting system. There may be an issue with the defrosting sensor or control circuit. Check the system and replace faulty components if needed.
LG.CH73: Error in the outdoor defrosting system. There may be an issue with the defrosting sensor or control circuit. Check the system and replace faulty components if needed.
LG.CH74: Error in the indoor defrosting system. There may be an issue with the defrosting sensor or control circuit. Check the system and replace faulty components if needed.
LG.CH75: Error in the outdoor defrosting system. There may be an issue with the defrosting sensor or control circuit. Check the system and replace faulty components if needed.
LG.CH90: Error in the indoor unit control board. The problem may be caused by a short circuit or a fault in the control system. Check and replace the board if needed.
LG.CH91: Error in the outdoor unit control board. The problem may be caused by a short circuit or a fault in the control system. Check and replace the board if needed.
LG.CH92: High or low voltage reaching the outdoor unit. Check the power supply and ensure the air conditioner is receiving proper voltage.
LG.CH93: Error in the air conditioner's power supply system. Check the electrical connections and ensure there are no short circuits or disconnections.
LG.CH94: Compressor thermal overload. The compressor may be working excessively, or the pressure in the system is higher than normal. Check the airflow and the gas condition.
LG.CH95: High pressure in the cooling system. The filters may be dirty, the condenser may be blocked, or there may be a fault in the compressor. Clean the filters and check the gas pressure.
LG.CH96: Low pressure in the cooling system. There may be a refrigerant shortage, leak, or fault in the compressor. Check the system and recharge the gas if needed.
LG.CH97: Compressor temperature is too high. There may be an issue with the outdoor unit fan, a compressor fault, or a refrigerant shortage.
LG.CH98: Compressor temperature protection. When the temperature is too high, the system will stop operating to prevent damage.
LG.CH99: Lack of refrigerant or improper refrigerant flow. Check the refrigerant pressure and the pipes in the system.
LG.C1: Error in the indoor temperature sensor.
LG.C2: Error in the outdoor temperature sensor.
LG.C3: Communication error between the internal and external boards.
LG.C4: Error in the indoor fan motor.
LG.C5: Error in the outdoor fan motor.
LG.C6: Error in the indoor unit control board.
LG.C7: Error in the outdoor unit control board.
LG.C8: Error in the cooling flow system.
LG.P1: High-pressure protection on the compressor. Check the gas pressure and the internal system.
LG.P2: Low-pressure protection on the compressor. There may be a refrigerant shortage or leak in the system.
LG.P4: Error in the automatic defrost system.
LG.P5: Error in the gas system or refrigerant shortage.
LG.P6: Error in the electronic control system.
LG.P7: Error in the electrical system or excessive current on the compressor.
LG.P8: Error in the electronic expansion valve.
LG.P9: Error in the gas flow system or control valve.
LG.F3: Faulty gas pressure sensor or improperly connected.
LG.F7: Problem with the main control board.
LG.F8: Problem with the compressor control board.
LG.F9: Overheating in the compressor due to overload.

Electra.E1: Error in the room temperature sensor in the indoor unit. The sensor may not be properly connected or may be faulty. It is recommended to call a technician to check and replace the sensor if necessary.
Electra.E2: Error in the condenser battery sensor in the outdoor unit. Check the sensor connection and ensure it is working properly. If needed, replace it.
Electra.E3: Error in the evaporator battery sensor in the indoor unit. The sensor measures the refrigerant temperature in the system. When the temperature is outside the correct range, the sensor may stop functioning. Check and replace the sensor if needed.
Electra.E4: Error in the fan motor, control board, or evaporator capacitor in the indoor unit. Call a technician to check and replace the components if needed.
Electra.E5: Communication error between the indoor and outdoor units. The connecting cable may be faulty, or there may be an issue with the control board. Check the cable and boards and replace them if needed.
Electra.E6: Error in the evaporator battery sensor. Check the sensor and replace it if needed.
Electra.E9: Error in the evaporator control board. Call a technician to check and replace the board if needed.
Electra.F1: High voltage in the condenser. The problem may be due to a refrigerant shortage, a fault in the outdoor fan, or the condenser control board. Call a technician to check the system.
Electra.F2: Error in the condenser control board. The board consists of three parts: power board, communication board, and capacitor board. Check which part is faulty and replace it.
Electra.F3: Error in the compressor. The problem may be due to a fault in the control board or the compressor itself. In such cases, replacing the compressor may be expensive and not always worth it.
Electra.F4: Error in the compressor temperature sensor. The sensor may be disconnected or faulty. Check the sensor and replace it if needed.
Electra.F5: Error in the compressor temperature. The compressor is overheating and stops working. Check the compressor cooling system.
Electra.F6: Error in the air sensor located on the condenser battery. Ensure that the sensor is connected and not faulty.
Electra.F7: High or low voltage in the condenser control board. Check the electrical voltage and replace the board if needed.
Electra.F8: Error in the communication in the condenser control board. Check the board and replace it if needed.
Electra.F9: Error in the condenser control board due to a short circuit or fault. Check the board and replace it if needed.
Electra.F0: Error in the outdoor fan motor. Check the motor and replace it if needed.
Electra.FA: Error in the suction temperature sensor in the condenser. Ensure that the sensor is connected and not faulty.
Electra.EC: The refrigerant pressure in the system is not correct, likely due to a refrigerant shortage. In this case, the air conditioner will not cool or heat properly. Call a technician to locate and fix the leak and recharge the gas.

Tornado.E0: EEPROM error in the outdoor unit.
Tornado.E1: Overcurrent protection on the evaporator. Check the power supply voltage and the operating current. If they are correct, the control board may need replacement.
Tornado.E2: Communication error between the indoor and outdoor units. The issue may be due to a faulty communication cable or a short circuit in one of the internal boards.
Tornado.E3: Communication error between DSP and outdoor units.
Tornado.E4: Error in the T4 temperature sensor. The sensor may be shorted or disconnected. Check the sensor condition.
Tornado.E5: Compressor voltage protection. The issue may be due to too low electrical voltage or a fault in the compressor control board.
Tornado.E6: Communication error between the indoor and outdoor units. The issue may be due to a damaged cable or a faulty control board.
Tornado.E8: Error in the sensor located on the evaporator battery. The sensor may be reading the temperature incorrectly or may be faulty.
Tornado.F0: Refrigerant shortage in the air conditioning system. Check the refrigerant pressure and refill if necessary.
Tornado.F1: Error in the temperature sensor located in the indoor unit. The sensor may be shorted or disconnected.
Tornado.F2: Error in the temperature sensor measuring the evaporator temperature. The sensor may be disconnected or shorted.
Tornado.F3: Error in the compressor. Common causes include a fault in the control board responsible for the compressor startup or a fault in the compressor itself.
Tornado.F4: Error in the compressor temperature sensor. The sensor may be faulty or the compressor may be overheating.
Tornado.F6: Error in the return air sensor located on the condenser. The issue may be in the outdoor fan or the fan motor.
Tornado.P1: The system entered high-pressure protection mode. Possible causes: clogged filters, dirty battery, or blockage in the outdoor unit ventilation openings.
Tornado.P2: The system entered low-pressure protection mode. Possible causes: clogged filters or refrigerant shortage in the system.
Tornado.P6: The outdoor unit entered self-protection mode. Common causes: a fault in the compressor or the control board of the outdoor unit.
Tornado.EC: The refrigerant pressure in the air conditioner is not correct, likely due to a refrigerant shortage. Call a technician to locate and fix the leak and recharge the gas.

Bosch.E1: Phase sequence error or communication error between the indoor and outdoor units.
Bosch.E2: Communication error between the indoor unit and the master unit or error in the indoor environment temperature sensor (T1).
Bosch.E4: Temperature sensor error T3/T4 or error in the internal heat exchanger outlet temperature sensor (T2B).
Bosch.E7: Error in the exhaust temperature sensor or EEPROM error.
Bosch.E9: EEPROM memory mismatch in the compressor.
Bosch.F1: DC voltage error in the bus path.
Bosch.F3: Error in the temperature sensor T6B.
Bosch.F5: Error in the temperature sensor T6A.
Bosch.F6: Error in the connection of the electronic expansion valve.
Bosch.H0: Communication error between the main board and the compressor control board.
Bosch.H2: Number of outdoor units decreased abnormally.
Bosch.H3: Number of outdoor units decreased abnormally.
Bosch.H5: P2 protection triggered three times within 60 minutes.
Bosch.H6: P2 protection triggered three times within 60 minutes.
Bosch.H7: Mismatch in the number of indoor units.
Bosch.H9: P9 protection triggered ten times within 120 minutes.
Bosch.C7: PL protection triggered three times within 100 minutes.
Bosch.P1: High-pressure protection or exhaust temperature switch protection.
Bosch.PP: Overheat protection in the compressor discharge.
Bosch.L1: Low DC voltage protection in the bus path.
Bosch.L2: High DC voltage protection in the bus path.
Bosch.L8: Compressor frequency protection when the frequency changes by more than 15 Hz within one second.
Bosch.L9: Protection when the actual compressor frequency deviates by more than 15 Hz from the scheduled frequency.
Bosch.E3: Temperature sensor error at the mid-point of the internal heat exchanger (T2).
Bosch.Eb: Internal electronic expansion valve coil error.
Bosch.FE: No address allocated to the indoor unit.
